chapter.title: Tuning
chapter.para: This chapter presents information about tuning &s4sa; to work optimally with &sap; applications.

note.title: Choosing between sapconf and saptune
note.para: On &s4s; you have the choice between sapconf and saptune. However, saptune is the more elaborate tool that offers more features.

sect1.title: Tuning Systems with &sapconf; 4
sect1.para: The package sapconf is available for the &x86-64; and &ppc64le; architecture. This package contains the tuned profile sapconf. This single tuning profile sets recommended parameters for the following types of &sap; applications: &netweaver;, &hana; and &hana;-based applications.

listitem.para: sap-netweaver (&tuned; profile)
sap-hana (&tuned; profile)
sap-bobj (&tuned; profile)
sap-ase (&tuned; profile)
&sapconf; (&tuned; profile)

sect1.para: Note that if you previously made changes to the system tuning, those changes may be overwritten by the &sapconf; profile.

listitem.para: A &systemd; service that ensures &tuned; and related services are running and the sapconf profile is applied.
The &tuned; profile sapconf that applies configured &sapconf; tuning parameters using a script and configuration files.

sect1.para: To use &sapconf;, make sure that the packages tuned and sapconf are installed on your system.

note.title: sapconf Utility Is Not Included in &productname; &productnumber;
note.para: The command-line utility sapconf that was included in &productname; 11 and 12 is not available anymore in &productname; &productnumber;.

note.title: Unified Profiles in &productname; &productnumber;
note.para: In &productname; 15 and above, only a single &tuned; profile, sapconf, is shipped. It is equivalent to the profiles sap-hana/sap-netweaver shipped in earlier versions of &productname;.

Log messages related to this file are written to /var/log/sapconf.log.

sect2.title: Using tuned Together with &sapconf;
sect2.para: With version 5 &sapconf; does not rely on &tuned; anymore. This means both tools can be used independently. &sapconf; will print a warning in it's log if tuned service is started.

note.title: Important: Using tuned and &sapconf; together
note.para: If you are going to use tuned and &sapconf; simultaneously, be very careful, that bot tools do not configure the same system parameters.

sect1.title: Tuning Systems with &saptune;
sect1.para: Using &saptune;, you can tune a system for &netweaver;, &hana;/&bo;, and &s4h; applications. This method relies on the system tuning service &tuned;.
To use &saptune;, make sure that the packages tuned and saptune are installed on your system.

note.title: &tuned; Daemon
note.para: &sapconf; (only version 4) and &saptune; both rely on the daemon &tuned; to set tuning configuration but they use different (though very similar) tuning profiles. Therefore, only one of &sapconf; or &saptune; can be enabled at a time.

sect1.title: Tuning Kernel Parameters Manually Using sysctl
sect1.para: In addition to or instead of tuning kernel parameters using &sapconf;/&saptune;, you can also use sysctl to make manual adjustments to kernel parameters. However, such changes using sysctl do not persist across reboots by default. To make them persist across reboots, add them to one of the configuration files read by sysctl.

tip.title: sysctl and &saptune;
tip.para: If you plan to configure sysctl parameters for your &sap; system, consider using &saptune; as the central tool for managing such configurations.

sect1.para: For more information about sysctl, see the man pages sysctl(8), sysctl.conf(5), and sysctl.d(5).

sect1.title: Tuning Workload Memory Protection
sect1.para: Since &slsreg; 15, the page cache limit functionality has been replaced by workload memory protection using cgroups.
The idea is to put &sap; processes into a dedicated cgroup and protect memory by setting the memory.low interface file.

The kernel will try to keep the configured amount of memory as long as possible in physical memory. This protects SAP workload for being swapped out to disk. Service Pack 2 contains an significant update of workload memory protection.
